Investment bank RBC Capital Markets has come out with its top tech stock picks for 2017 and the list includes such big names as Apple (AAPL), Broadcom (AVGO) and Nvidia (NVDA).In a research report Thursday, RBC analysts Amit Daryanani and Mitch Steves chose those companies along with Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Texas Instruments (TXN) as their top large-cap stock ideas for 2017 in the tech sector.They also made five small and midcap picks: Amphenol (APH), Analog Devices (ADI), Arris International (ARRS), CDW (CDW) and Microsemi (MSCC).RBC likes Apple because of the potential for an iPhone 8 supercycle of upgrade activity, as well as its growing services business (Apple Music, Apple Pay, iCloud, etc.) and the possible repatriation of foreign profits.It has a price target on Apple of 125. Apple stock rose 0.2% to 116.52 on the stock market today. Apple is building a cup-shaped base with a 118.79 buy point.IBD'S TAKE: Among RBC's top 10 tech stock picks for 2017, two are on the IBD 50 list of top growth stocks: Nvidia and Microsemi.Chipmaker Broadcom is likely to benefit from deal integration and an improved capital structure, RBC said. Broadcom merged with Avago Technologies in February. It is in the process of acquiring Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD).RBC has a price target on Broadcom of 200. The stock rose 0.74% Friday, to 181.94. Broadcom broke out of a flat base with a buy point of 179.52 on Dec. 9 and is trading within a buy range.Cisco is attractive because of its mix shift away from switching and routing, continued M&A and the potential for repatriation, the analysts said. RBC has a price target on Cisco of 35. It rose 0.23% to 30.53 on Friday.Graphics chipmaker Nvidia offers the "cleanest secular growth story" in the group, enjoying tailwinds from virtual reality, artificial intelligence and autonomous driving, RBC said. It has a price target of 115 on Nvidia stock, which jumped 2.5% Friday to 109.78, touching an all-time high for the seventh day in the past eight trading days.Chipmaker Texas Instruments is well positioned for gross-margin upside and sales growth acceleration driven by market share gains, RBC said. It has a price target on TI of 80. The stock rose 0.24% Friday, to 74.38.RBC predicts that "Trumponomics" will help many tech companies in 2017. President-elect Donald Trump is expected to push for lower corporate tax rates and a tax holiday on repatriating foreign profits parked overseas. Apple and U.S. semiconductor firms would be key beneficiaries, they said."Trumponomics should drive the narrative for 2017 given widespread implications for our coverage group," Daryanani and Steves said. "Beyond that, we think fundamentals will enable a better revenue and margin narrative for most companies in 2017 with continued focus on M&A."The iPhone 8 could trigger a supercycle given the aging installed base of iPhones in use, RBC said. The supercycle also should benefit component suppliers such as Broadcom.Chip suppliers also will be aided by the launch of Samsung's Galaxy S8 handset and growing smartphone sales in India, RBC said.Potential headwinds in the New Year for IT companies include a possible U.S.-China trade war, given Trump's rhetoric about imposing tariffs on imports. Political turmoil in Europe is another possible headwind, RBC said. RELATED:Apple Seen Offering iPhone 7S, iPhone 8 Models In 2017Nvidia Nails Record High, Inphi Gets Price-Target Hike

Stocks were little changed Thursday morning, while top chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) continued to slide.The Dow industrials climbed 0.1%, the S&P 500 nearly 0.1% while the Nasdaq was fractionally lower.Graphics chipmaker Nvidia fell 3.7% to 105.17 in early trading on the stock market today. But that's down from 49.1% in a similar period in 2015 and 51.3% in 2014.Samsung showed a slight increase, accounting for 21% of activations vs. 19.3% a year earlier. Meanwhile, Alphabet (GOOGL) failed to generate much buzz for its new Google Pixel phones. Alphabet's two models, though well-reviewed, accounted for few activations, Flurry said.Apple shares were flat in morning trade. Alphabet was down 0.3%. A week ago, semiconductor ETFs were selling off and looking dangerous. But now, they've bounced back impressively.The sector was roiled Dec. 1, with many chip stocks suffering their worst drops in months. The exact cause was unclear. Worries over soft iPhone demand contributed to the selling.The sell-off caused the three chip ETFs in IBD's ETF Leaders screen to fall to their 50-day moving averages, but at that key level shares found support and have been rising. That's a bullish recovery. However, the quick rebounds have left the ETFs largely extended from proper buy areas. Investors must wait for a new pullback or another type of follow-on entry to find another chance to invest.In all three cases, the funds broke out of bases in mid-November and made only modest progress before they got pulled down by the undertow of the Dec. 1 sell-off.SPDR S&P Semiconductor (XSD) made a record high this week. It had broke out past a 53.88 buy point Nov. 17. The fund is primarily a smaller-capitalization vehicle in the chip space, with about 40 stocks averaging about $7 billion in market cap.Its three largest holdings — Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Nvidia (NVDA) and Microsemi (MSCC) — have produced stupendous returns since November and reached new highs this week. In fact, their advances may be getting overheated.IShares PHLX Semiconductor ETF (SOXX) also is at all-time highs, tracing a chart quite similar to SPDR S&P Semiconductor. The fund tracks the Philadelphia semiconductor index, a well-known sector gauge that often goes by the nickname "Sox."It is a more-focused portfolio, with 30 components that form a blend of mid- and large-cap stocks. The fund also has been well-served by owning Nvidia — the largest holding, at 10.6% weighting. But other major holdings, such as Intel (INTC), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Qualcomm (QCOM), have had much more sedate price performance the past few months.VanEck Vectors Semiconductor (SMH) started trading in May 2000, when the tech bubble was bursting. It has yet to reach the record levels that it achieved back then. But today it's acting as well as the other chip ETFs. At 4% above the 50-day moving average, it  is not yet extended.The fund owns about 25 companies in semiconductor production and equipment, with Intel and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) the biggest components, at 14% weighting each.The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. Apple (AAPL), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Applied Materials (AMAT) and Texas Instruments (TXN) are near or above buy points, while Facebook (FB) is hitting resistance at its 200-day line.Despite some notable swings lately, Apple shares didn't rise or fall enough to invalidate their 110.33 buy point. The stock closed Friday at 110.06.The sell-off of major consumer tech stocks since the election of Donald Trump as U.S. president has created a buying opportunity for investors, investment bank Piper Jaffray said in a research report Thursday, naming Apple, Facebook, Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon (AMZN) and Netflix (NFLX).IBD 50 chip equipment maker Applied Materials is just 1.4% below a 31.17 buy point after Friday's fractional gain. Applied Materials actually rose as high as 31.25 intraday Friday, but settled for a 1-cent gain. The move came after the company reported mixed results with strong guidance late Thursday.RELATED:Applied Materials Hits 16-Year High, Then Retreats, After Q4 EarningsMeanwhile, semiconductor maker Texas Instruments has broken out of a nearly four-month long flat base with a 72.28 buy point. Shares closed Friday up 0.7% at 72.60, though volume was only 5% above normal.Late last month, the chipmaker reported view-topping earnings, but the midpoint of its revenue guidance was below views.Palo Alto shares hit a new 10-month high on Thursday, solidly entering buy range from a flat base with a 163.11 buy point.But the stock dipped back below that level on Friday, dropping 1.7% to 161.35. Palo Alto reports earnings on Monday. could fuel shares back into the buy zone, or past it, if it beats.RELATED:Top Security Software Stocks Near Buy Points Palo Alto Networks Breaks Out Ahead Of Earnings, Price-Target Hiked The social networking giant breached its 200-day line for the first time in nearly nine months on Nov. 10. Last Monday, the stock hit a four-month low, and it has been hitting resistance below the key 200-day line ever since. It retook that level intraday Friday but closed below it. The stock is now 12% below its late October high.Facebook rose about 1% late Friday after announcing a $6 billion buyback plan.Most tech stocks have been rebounding after getting hit after the election, but Facebook is notably struggling. It recently acknowledged finding new glitches in how it measures user engagement and came under criticism for allowing fake news to proliferate on its site during the campaign. It and Alphabet's Google have said they will ban fake news sites from using their advertising networks. Facebook also warned in its last quarterly report of slowing ad revenue growth in 2017.RELATED:Facebook Will Buy Back $6 Billion In Shares As Stock Slide Continues

But when the chip gear makers decided not to get hitched in early October, both stocks rallied.Texas Instruments climbed 1.2% to 72.08, after rising to 72.28 intraday, exactly matching its buy point.TI is in a flat base going back to late July. TI gapped up to a longtime high on July 26 following strong quarterly results.Applied Materials climbed 2.4% to 30.73 after rising above its 50-day line on Tuesday.The stock is approaching a 31.17 buy point.The chip gear giant reported better-than-exected earnings after Thursday's market close. When financial advisors shop for technology to improve their practice, they often draw two conclusions: It's expensive. And it's complex.But some of the best financial advisor technology tools come at a low cost. Better yet, they're easy to learn and fun to use.Online financial calculators enable advisors to enter client data and get quick results or recommendations. These tools can compute everything from life insurance needs to mortgage payments to required minimum distribution from a tax-deferred savings vehicle such as a 401(k) or IRA.At their best, calculators allow advisors to make reasonable financial projections well into the future. Retirement planning calculators, for example, show clients how much money they might need after they quit working — and whether their current saving and spending plan can advance them toward their goal.The interactive nature of these tools can heighten client engagement in the financial planning process. In examining their retirement plan, individuals can compare their projected savings with their goal and then test different scenarios to see how tweaking the numbers might influence long-term results.Advisors can use calculators to illustrate how certain actions, such as sticking to a budget, can increase a client's financial security for decades. In annual reviews, they can run updated simulations based on a client's recent life events or changes to retirement goals.Anna Sergunina, a certified financial planner in Burlingame, Calif., favors Bankrate.com's mortgage calculator. She uses the free program to estimate a client's monthly amount due, assess affordability and explore the impact of making extra principal payments."I like it because it's clean and simple," she said. "It helps me show clients how their mortgage can be paid off. We do it together the first time and we have an answer. Then we can revisit it later."Unlike more elaborate technology platforms and products, online calculators are fairly easy to design. Some advisors build their own calculator and hire a tech-savvy programmer to help develop it.But if you intend to use a calculator created by someone else, do due diligence. Check its validity by researching users' experience and confirming that it performs as promised.Insurance expert John Ryan suggests that advisors consider four factors when evaluating an online calculator, especially those that focus on life insurance and long-term-care insurance."You want to see if it has any bias built into it, if it's accurate in terms of its needs analysis and conclusions, and what assumptions it uses," said Ryan, principal at Ryan Insurance Strategy Consultants in Greenwood Village, Colo. "Also, how does it capture information? Will a salesperson follow up with you?"Ryan created his own insurance-needs calculators for advisors to use with their clients. Initially, his online tools did not list assumptions that went into the calculations, such as whether one's children would attend public or private schools and the resulting cost differential."Several years ago, we improved our calculators to explain our assumptions," he said. "It's important for an advisor to know what assumptions are used and whether they are explained and defined."Like deciding how much life insurance to buy, estimating tax liability or withholdings becomes more manageable with a reliable calculating tool. Some online calculators help advisors with number-crunching exercises such as tax planning.Ray Evans, a certified financial planner in Overland Park, Kan., likes TaxCaster, a free income-tax calculator on the TurboTax website. Evans says it helps him address issues such as computing capital gains tax on a potential stock sale and forecasting how much a client will owe in taxes. He uses other calculators to guide clients' decisions on whether to refinance a mortgage or buy or lease a car.Despite the ever-growing number of online calculators, some advisors opt for offline resources. Patrick Dougherty, a Dallas-based certified financial planner, covets a handheld financial calculator called the BAII Plus, made by Texas Instruments (TXN)."I find it so intuitive and easy to use," he said. "It's actually easier than using a computer. I know it sounds old school, but clients appreciate how I can answer their questions really quickly" on everything from mortgage amortization to calculating the rate of return on a real estate investment over many years.Dougherty teaches financial planning courses to students interested in becoming advisors. He urges them to get acquainted with the BAII Plus and even use it during their test to earn the certified financial planner certification. He adds that it's one of the few devices that they're allowed to have during the exam.

The stock topped its all-time high of 131.98 and closed Friday just a penny below a secondary buy point of 132.08.Ahead of the holiday shopping season, big-box consumer-electronics retailer Best Buy is 2% below a 40.31 buy point as it works on the handle of a cup-with-handle base.Texas Instruments found support at the 50-day line and is 3.8% below a potential buy point at 72.68, ahead of its quarterly earnings on Wednesday. Stocks remained mildly in the red at lunchtime on Monday. Big-cap techs showed mixed action, but Tesla Motors (TSLA) was showing decisively negative action again.The EV maker fell more than 2% to 192.29, taking out a recent August low of 193.45. The stock is now 29% below a 52-week high of 269.34.The Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrials all sank 0.1% or less. Volume in New York was running at a slower pace vs. the same time Friday, despite Bank of America's (BAC) surprise rise in Q3 earnings to 41 cents a share, up 8%. The Street was looking for 34 cents, or a 10.5% decline vs. a year ago.Bank of America initially rallied more than 1% but backtracked to a 0.5% loss in fast turnover. The stock is near a 16.34 buy point within a long bottoming-style cup with handle pattern. BofA's Relative Price Strength Rating is not shabby at 75, meaning it's now outperforming 75% of all companies in IBD's database.Meanwhile, among top-performing big caps, Texas Instruments (TXN) rallied nearly 0.6% to 68.88. The chipmaker has formed a nearly three-month-old flat base with a 72.68 buy point. Texas is in the IBD Big Cap 20, which has as many as 15 companies that showed double-digit revenue growth in the second quarter, bucking the slow gains in the U.S. economy.Texas is part of the market-leading semiconductor manufacturing industry group, which ranks 12th out of 197 IBD industry groups in 12-month relative price-weighted performance.Tesla is pushing back its new product announcement from Monday to Wednesday after CEO Elon Musk said in a tweet that the company needed time for "refinement," without getting more specific.The stock had gotten a nice boost in mid-September to early October thanks to better than expected deliveries for Q3, giving investors confidence in Tesla making its full-year goals. But the stock's rebound stopped short of rebounding back above its 50- and 200-day moving averages — a key ingredient in developing a new base and potential breakout to new highs.As seen in a daily chart at Investors.com, Tesla's RS line (seen in blue), which compares a stock's price change vs. the S&P 500, has been falling again in the past two weeks.Elsewhere in the stock market today, Hasbro (HAS) leapt 7% to 81.72, rebounding back above its 50- and 200-day moving averages simultaneously in heavy volume.The toy maker, which makes a variety of Star Wars-themed games, devices and action figures, announced a 28% jump in third-quarter earnings to $2.03 a share, sharply beating the $1.74 consensus estimate. That marked the fifth quarter of profit growth and followed robust gains of 81% and 24% in the prior two quarters. Sales grew 14% to $1.68 billion, accelerating from a 10% increase in Q2.On average, sales have now grown 13% vs. year-ago levels in the past four quarters. In Q2, growth in the U.S.-Canada region of 16% exceeded the international region's 13% increase, which includes currency factors.The stock has been constructing a long flat base since its peak of 88.53 on April 19. The weak 22 RS Rating, according to IBD Stock Checkup, reflects the stock's sideways movement since late July. Watch to see if this rating can improve; also, a continued rally into the 85-87 price area would give the stock a shot at a breakout.RELATED:Musk: Tesla Delays 'Unexpected' Product News To Wednesday For 'Refinement'Do You Know How To Identify The Bottoming Base?Seek Speedy Cheetahs Among Big Cap Stocks In This Slowpoke EconomyThank You, Walt Disney: Hasbro Reports A Solid Third Quarter

Texas Instruments (TXN) could be a surprise candidate to step in and acquire NXP Semiconductor (NXPI), a move that would leave Qualcomm (QCOM) in the dust, says Nomura."It almost seems inevitable that NXP will be acquired," wrote Nomura analyst Romit Shah in a research note Tuesday. Dow Jones last week was first to report that Qualcomm is looking to acquire NXP for about $30 billion.Like Qualcomm, Texas Instruments is one of the top 10 chip companies worldwide. TI specializes in analog chips and embedded processors. NXP makes high-performance mixed-signal processors for communications, security, automotive and industrial applications, and its shares quintupled 2012-2014 before slowing in the past 16 months."Most investors expect Qualcomm to win the process," Shah wrote. "While we don't disagree, we also see Texas Instruments as a dark horse that hasn't been seriously thought of and could rush past the field in triumph."Shah says Texas Instruments is overdue to make a big acquisition, having made 33 over the past 20 years but none in the past five years.Buying NXP would boost Texas Instruments' microcontroller market share to No. 1 from No. 7. NXP is the leading supplier of non-automotive microcontroller units and second in industrial and automotive application processors, says Shah. Also, NXP would lift Texas Instruments from the fourth-largest to the second-largest non-memory semiconductor company by revenue, Shah wrote.Moreover, NXP CEO Rick Clemmer and Chairman Peter Bonfield are former TI employees, says Shah."We believe that Clemmer maintains close ties with the TI management team, while Bonfield has spoken publicly about his affection for Texas Instruments," Shah wrote.NXP stock closed at 103.23, up a fraction, in the stock market today. Shares jumped 17% on Thursday, on reports of Qualcomm's interest, and have risen another seven percentage points since then. Texas Instruments slipped a fraction Tuesday, to 69.59.IBD'S TAKE: Big mergers often come with big challenges, and many never pan out. For an example of huge deal that so far is working out, look no further than the latest IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks over the past 52 weeks. Broadcom, a product of a merger completed early this year between Broadcom and Avago, resides at No. 36. More than that, Broadcom also is among IBD's Sector Leaders.Assuming NXP gets acquired, it would be part of a wave of consolidation occurring in the chip sector.RELATED:NXP Hires Adviser To Field Offers As Qualcomm CirclesTexas Instruments, Inphi, Yum Lead Wednesday Investing Action Plan

With chipmakers the No. 2 sector in IBD's tables, three semiconductor ETFs have earned spots in the ETF Leaders screen.All three ETFs are tracing similar chart patterns: After strong gains from July breakouts, they are pausing at the 50-day moving average. A rise from the line would provide ETF traders with a chance to buy shares. While tactically there's a buy opportunity, keep in mind that these ETFs have already made a big jump -- up 18% to 28% this year. Thus, investors have a difficult decision on whether to use one of these ETFs to gain exposure to the hot sector.VanEck Vector Semiconductor (SMH) and iShares PHLX Semiconductor (SOXX) bulk up on the industry titans. Qualcomm (QCOM), Intel (INTC), Broadcom (AVGO), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) are among the largest holdings of both funds.Those stocks have made moderate to solid gains this year, and are no doubt largely responsible for the ETFs' advance. But Nvidia (NVDA), another top holding of the funds, has had a superlative 2016, more than doubling since a breakout in mid-March. Best known for graphics chips, Nvidia is now a big player is the technology to design self-driving cars.The iShares Semiconductor ETF mimics the Philadelphia semiconductor index, or SOX as it's best known. It has 30 companies, which include the industry heavyweights.SPDR S&P Semiconductor (XSD) ETF has a markedly different composition than the other two. That may explain why the ETF has lagged the other two. It's up 18% year to date (through Thursday's close), while VanEck Semiconductors has climbed nearly 28% and iShares Semiconductors 23%.The major components of SPDR S&P Semiconductor aren't all big-capitalization stocks, but also include small-caps and midcaps such as Synaptics (SYNA) (market cap of $2.4 billion), Cirrus Logic (CRUS) ($3.4 billion) and solar-power module maker First Solar (FSLR) ($4.3 billion).SPDR S&P Semiconductor tracks an index of chip companies selected mainly for their revenue but also earnings, market capitalization and "market perception," as the prospectus says.IBD's chip sector is up about 17% this year, thanks in part to higher-than-expected demand for the new Apple iPhone 7, increasing use of electronics in the home (the Internet of Things) and chips in cars. Even with the flop of the Samsung Note 7, the chip sector has been one of 2016's winners. Broadcom and Qualcomm are suppliers to iPhone and Samsung smartphones.The information technology sector continues to lead with the most positive earnings guidance. For Q3, that includes eight of 15 S&P 500 companies in semiconductor and chip equipment, according to a Sept. 28 report by FactSet.The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. The universe from which the ETFs are selected includes the funds listed below.          RELATED:KLA-Tencor, AMD, Maxim Integrated Earnings Top Views; Chip Stocks DivergeIntel Beats Q3 Targets, But Q4 Sales Forecast Lags

Seattle-based Impinj (PI), a provider of inventory-tracking technology using radio frequency identification (RFID) tags, has been a hot stock since its initial public offering this summer.Impinj went public on July 21 at 14 and climbed as high as 37.86 on Sept. 14. But shares tumbled 6.2% to close at 32.13 on the stock market today, even though Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brad Erickson late Sunday reiterated his overweight rating on Impinj stock and raised his price target to 36 from 29.IBD'S TAKE: The stock market's newest companies are where you find some of the biggest winning stocks. Check out IBD's IPO Leaders stock list for a proprietary screen of recent IPOs with strong fundamental and technical traits."After hosting PI's management team for investor meetings last week, we came away incrementally more confident in its competitive moat, near-term inventory levels and the likely critical need for its software," Erickson said in his research report.Impinj is a player in the Internet of Things (IoT). It sells systems that use RAIN RFID to track items for retail, pharmaceutical, health care, food and beverage, manufacturing and other industries. RAIN RFID is a wireless technology standard for connecting items to the internet, enabling businesses to identify, locate and check the status of each item. RAIN is an acronym derived from radio frequency identification.The biggest concerns related to Impinj are commoditization and product differentiation, Erickson said."We came away more confident that attributes like read range, patented chip design and antenna tuning have led to its 65% market share," he said.Larger companies such as Texas Instruments (TXN) and Microchip (MCHP)-owned Atmel have tried their hand at UHF RFID and failed, so Impinj's technology likely solves more challenging problems than many investors realize, he said.RELATED:Impinj Soars To New High As First Earnings Since IPO Connects

Scanning IBD DataTables for income ideas was a lot easier earlier this year.Even the IBD 50, the premier list of strength in the stock market, was littered with stocks sporting healthy dividends, especially from the utilities and real estate investment trusts (REITs).Contrast that to today, when a screen of utilities leaders only yielded a couple names as of Wednesday's close, both of them breaking support levels. A screen of REIT leaders offers a dozen names but only one is above its 50-day moving average and none has a Relative Price Strength Rating above 80.The Dividend Leaders screen, however, does have a few ideas of interest. Particularly, noteworthy are a couple chip stocks, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM).Qualcomm is still a dominant force in the mobile-phone market with its chip designs in mobile products of Apple (AAPL), Samsung, and now Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Pixel. While, no one is expecting Qualcomm to "party like its 1999" when it ran up over 2,000%, it still offers an attractive dividend with the potential for capital appreciation.Granted, Qualcomm doesn't have the triple-digit earnings growth it had in its youth. In fact, prior to its 17% growth for its fiscal Q3 in 2016, the company saw four consecutive quarters of profit declines. Qualcomm is scheduled to report its fourth quarter, ended in September, on Nov. 2 after the close.March 2016 saw a completion of a one-year commitment to repurchase $10 billion in stock and the quarterly dividend was raised to 53 cents earlier this year. That was the 15th dividend increase since 2003, putting the annualized yield at 3.2%.The most recent news on Qualcomm is the rumors of a potential acquisition of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI). NXP makes high-performance mixed signal processors for communications, security, automotive and industrial applications. An acquisition of NXP offers more diversity for Qualcomm beyond the heavy reliance on mobile. Particularly interesting is the exposure to the auto-related chips, a fast-growing field.Meanwhile, Maxim is noteworthy for the current base its carving out. The stock is working on a base-on-base structure with its current flat base showing support right on top of the cup with handle formed earlier. The stock is currently trying to get back above its 50-day moving average, closing right at the line on Thursday.Maxim is a chipmaker specializing in integrated circuits for autos, cloud data centers, industrial and mobile applications. It has an annualized dividend yield of 3.3%. The company is reporting Q1 fiscal 2017 earnings on Oct. 20.Earlier this year, Maxim was also in the takeover buzz as a possible acquisition by Texas Instruments (TXN).The chart might seem like a real bore since there have actually been multiple bases formed at this point that haven't seemed able to launch. However, that action is not without precedent.Before Qualcomm's huge run in 1999, it also had multiple bases that didn't go anywhere, until it formed a near-perfect cup with handle that launched the stock for good. Of course, that was a different time with not only Qualcomm's earnings growth acting as a catalyst but also a strong market providing a powerful tailwind.RELATED:NXP Hires Advisor To Field Offers As Qualcomm CirclesQualcomm Gets More Upbeat Reviews on NXP Semi Merger RumorWhere Are Chipmakers In The Cycle

Investment bank Jefferies pounded the table for four analog chip stocks on Thursday, raising its price targets on Analog Devices (ADI), Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM), Microchip Technology (MCHP) and Texas Instruments (TXN).Jefferies rates all four stocks as buys.X"The combination of peak earnings, peak margins and stretching lead times in analog look like classic cyclical peak signals, but we think consolidation is the real culprit," Jefferies analyst Mark Lipacis said in a report. "We expect more consolidation, and profitability to go even higher."Analog stocks also are benefiting from secular drivers such as the Internet of Things, he said."If our Analog Renaissance thesis plays out, the 35%-40% operating margins this group is printing today will look medieval when compared to the 50% (margins) they will be pushing in 2022," Lipacis said.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks includes two chipmakers: Nvidia and Microchip Technology.Lipacis raised his price targets as follows: Analog Devices to 105 from 100, Maxim to 58 from 51, Microchip to 106 from 94, and Texas Instruments to 110 from 96.He also raised his price target on hold-rated ON Semiconductor (ON) to 20 from 16.Analog Devices was down 0.2% to close at 88.80 on the stock market today. Over the last three months, the top-performing mutual funds have continued to pick up shares in chip stocks like Applied Materials (AMAT) and Intel (INTC), as well as in building-related companies, including Thor Industries (THO), Pulte Group (PHM) and Stanley Black & Decker (SWK).XWith an eye toward the growth of industrial output, leading fund managers also invested in five chemical companies, including DowDuPont (DWDP), Sherwin-Williams (SHW) and plastics manufacturer Rogers (ROG).Fifty-one leading mutual funds also took a nearly $128 million gulp of energy drink leader Monster Beverage (MNST), which cleared a 57.35 buy point on, quite appropriately, Halloween.  The Coca-Cola (KO) partner is trading 1% above the entry, meaning it's still in the buy zone, which extends to 60.22.Monster sports a B+ Accumulation/Distribution Rating and five quarters of rising fund ownership. The maker of Monster Rehab and other drink brands is set to report Q3 earnings on Nov. 8, with analysts expecting 21% EPS growth. Note that it's risky to buy any stock just before it reports.DowDuPont received the biggest investment of any stock on the list, as 73 funds purchased $16.7 billion worth of shares. But that number is skewed by the merger of Dow Chemical Co. and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. that was just completed in September to create the new entity. The chemical giant's market cap stands at just over $88 billion, and the stock has eased back into the buy zone after become extended from a breakout in September.Forty-two funds invested just over $1.7 billion in leading chip stock Intel, which broke out on Oct. 2, then soared over 7% on Oct. 27 after reporting third-quarter earnings. Intel is now about 22% above the initial buy point.UnitedHealth (UNH) was the only other company to join the billion-dollar club, with 67 funds investing $1.2 billion.  The megacap managed-care stock has continued to climb since a breakout in March 2016, clearly boosted by seven quarters of rising fund ownership.Semiconductor stocks like IBD 50 members Applied Materials and Lam Research (LRCX) have been on a tear since the beginning of 2016, but it's a cyclical industry, so investors should be ready to lock in gains if the stocks begin to show topping action.In addition to Applied Materials, Lam Research, IBD Big Cap 20 stock Texas Instruments (TXN) and Intel, six more semiconductor-related companies made this month's list, a sign that institutional investors are continuing to put their chips on the table, so to speak. Time will tell if, in the short term, that turns out to be a good bet.Applied Materials is 19% above its recent 47.69 buy point in a later-stage cup with handle, putting just below a potential profit-taking zone. Lam Research is already in the 20% - 25% profit-taking area.Banking giant JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and automaker General Motors (GM) topped the list of new sells this month. JPMorgan showed 42 net sellers (89 selling minus 47 buying), while GM had 29 (43 selling, 14 buying).Megacap medical stock Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) came in third, with 24 net sellers (68 selling, 44 buying).Despite the selling, Johnson & Johnson is still within buy range after retaking a 137.18 entry on Oct. 17 after reporting a 13% rise in Q3 earnings.JPMorgan has continued to climb beyond a 95.32 buy point, but after reporting earnings on Oct. 24, General Motors has been giving back a chunk of the 25%-plus gains it made from a breakout in September. With a bullish quarterly report and guidance from Apple (AAPL), your stocks to watch this week are five iPhone suppliers or related plays: Broadcom Limited (AVGO), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), Texas Instruments (TXN), Applied Materials (AMAT), Qorvo (QRVO) and Qualcomm (QCOM).Apple cleared a cup-with-handle buy point of 160.97 on Oct. 27, days ahead of its quarterly report. With Apple up 2.6% to an all-time high Friday, shares are now extended from the 5% buy range.After a wild session Thursday, Broadcom is trading back above a 259.46 buy point initially cleared on Oct. 30. Friday's 5.4% gain puts shares at an all time high, with Broadcom just above the 5% buy range.Broadcom said Thursday morning that October-quarter revenue will be at the higher end of its range. On Friday, shares rallied on Apple's earnings as well as a report that Broadcom may make a bid for wireless chip giant Qualcomm (QCOM), which has been feuding with Apple and many countries around the world over its licensing agreements. Qualcomm leapt 13% to 61.81 Friday, its best level since January.Skyworks Solutions cleared a cup buy point of 110.71 on Oct. 30, and holding within its buy zone. Skyworks, which issues its quarterly results on Monday, seems to be hitting some resistance around the 114 price level.IBD'S TAKE: Apple is on a hot streak. For a look at other high-quality growth stocks at or near buying opportunities, make sure to check out Leaderboard.Applied Materials broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 47.69 buy point in September, and is now extended 18.6% from that level. When a stock becomes 20% extended from a buy point, that's usually a good time to take at least partial profits.Applied Materials, a chip- and display-equipment maker, is not an Apple supplier. But it should benefit from the use of OLED screens by Apple (in the Phone X) and other top manufacturers.Meanwhile, Texas Instruments is extended 16% from a cup-with-handle buy point of 84.34. The stock has been on a steady climb since clearing that level in heavy volume on Sept. 15.Qorvo tried to clear a 76.57 buy point from a sloppy cup-with-handle base this past week, but never closed above that level. Chipmaker Texas Instruments (TXN) received two price-target hikes on its stock Monday, a day before it is set to reveal its December-quarter results.X Jefferies raised its price target on TI to 150 from 111 and reiterated its buy rating on the stock. It also added the stock to its "franchise pick list." RBC Capital Markets upped its price target to 127 from 112 and maintained its outperform rating.Texas Instruments shares lost 2.2% to close at 119.44 on the stock market today. TI stock hit an all-time high of 119.98 on Thursday."We think TXN is uniquely positioned to benefit from multiple secular and cyclical trends," Jefferies analyst Mark Lipacis said in a report Monday. Those trends include the growth of Internet of Things devices and industrial chips."We view TXN as a critical supplier of components into IoT devices, which we expect will provide visibility and robust growth over the next 15 years," he said.IBD'S TAKE: Texas Instruments stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 97 out of a best-possible 99. But it ranks No. 3 in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group. To see which stocks lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Texas Instruments is well positioned to beat consensus views when it reports fourth-quarter results after the market close Tuesday, RBC analyst Amit Daryanani said in a report. TI also is likely to guide for March-quarter results in line or modestly ahead of Wall Street's forecasts, he said.Daryanani sees Texas Instruments benefiting from automotive and industrial markets.Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) chip suppliers were pressured Monday by continued reports of an iPhone production slowdown amid softer-than-expected sales.Broadcom (AVGO) fell 1.6% to close at 262.11, on Monday. Cirrus Logic (CRUS) lost 2.2% to finish at 51.60. Qorvo (QRVO) was down 3% to 66.34. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) slipped 0.5% to 98.72."There is a lot of investor concern with the smartphone supply chain over iPhone X weakness into the March quarter and seasonal weakness in the China market," Mizuho Securities analyst Vijay Rakesh said in a report Monday. "As we approach earnings for the smartphone RF (radio frequency) component suppliers, a look at stock performance over the last 3-6 months shows that many of these concerns appear priced in."Mizuho expects iPhone X shipments to fall 40% in the March quarter vs. the December quarter. It sees overall iPhone shipments down about 30% quarter to quarter.Elsewhere in the chip sector Monday, investment bank Goldman Sachs upgraded shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) to buy from neutral. It set a 12-month price target of 49.67 on its U.S. shares. The proliferation of semiconductors in electric vehicles is creating a big market opportunity for numerous suppliers, a Wall Street analyst said Thursday.X The report by Nomura analyst Romit Shah says the average semiconductor content per electric vehicle is about $924, more than triple what is in standard internal combustion gas-powered automobiles, based on data from STMicroelectronics (STM).Shah projects the category of alternative electric vehicles will grow to 53 million units by 2030, up from 3.4 million units in 2017, implying a compound annual growth rate of 23%."This is significantly higher than the overall automotive compound annual growth rate, which our Nomura colleagues estimate to be 2.2% over the same time frame," Shah wrote. "We believe that there are a number of major shifts in transportation technology that will expand the demand for automotive semiconductors by orders of magnitude."Some of the companies set to benefit from the growth in auto electronics include NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and Texas Instruments (TXN), as well as STMicroelectronics and Analog Devices (ADI).Among recent events about these companies, NXP on Friday announced new chip products for radar applications in automated driving. Analog Devices received at least six price-target increases to its stock after delivering a beat-and-raise quarterly report on Nov. 22.In addition, Texas Instruments is currently trading near a record high, while STMicroelectronics is forming a base with a 24.90 buy point as it gets set to report quarterly earnings on Jan. 24.Shah said he spent his summer at electric-car company Tesla (TSLA), where he also spent significant time analyzing the supply chain for alternative energy vehicles. The category includes hybrid vehicles, plug-in hybrid electric vehicles and battery electric vehicles, such as Tesla, which is in the process of rolling out its mass-market Model 3.He expects advanced driver assistance systems, autonomous driving, and powertrain electrification to be the biggest drivers of chip content. His report focused on the electrification of the powertrain, which is the primary piece of an electric vehicle, housing the batteries and other technologies that provide the power for vehicle performance.IBD'S TAKE: Never has the chip sector been more competitive, with more than 750 companies vying globally to build the insides of the next hot device or power future megacomputers. Investors will find it tricky to navigate the sector. Bookmark this page to stay on top of the latest news in chips.The market for semiconductor components related to the electrification of automobiles is projected by STMicroelectronics to grow at a 19% compound annual growth rate from 2016 to 2021, "significantly faster than the greater automotive semiconductor and overall semiconductor markets," Shah wrote.Internal combustion vehicles comprise the large majority of vehicles on the road today, making up 97% of the overall automotive market in 2016. That's expected to fall to about 58% of the overall automotive market by 2030, as alternative electric vehicles drive ahead, Shaw wrote.Shares of Tesla added 0.9% to close at 337.95 on the stock market today. Texas Instruments added 0.9% to 110.67, just below the record high of 110.98 it reached on Tuesday. Analog Devices gained 1.2% to 91.19, while STMicroelectronics climbed 2.3% to 24.02.YOU MIGHT ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Chip Stocks To Watch And Semiconductor Industry NewsSelf-Driving Cars: Why 2018 Will Be The Year The Rubber Hits The RoadTesla Receives Largest Order For Big-Rig Semi Truck From UPS5 Things To Watch For Tesla, GM, Ford Other Carmakers In 2018

In a strong market, Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) would be looking very attractive. The search giant's stock is close to a potential buy point, consolidating near record highs.In the current shaky market, investors should be cautious about making any purchases. But you should always be looking for quality stocks forming sound consolidations.Among those bullish patterns is the flat base, where leading stocks can catch their breath for several weeks before trying to make a new advance. Flat bases are common now given the market's subdued, sideways action until the last week or so.Alphabet leads four top-rated stocks that are in flat bases. All four -- the others are Nvidia (NVDA), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Equifax (EFX) -- have found support at or near the 50-day moving average recently.IBD'S TAKE: The flat base is a sideways pattern, with a smaller decline than in other patterns. It can be of short duration (minimum five weeks) and often forms after a breakout from a cup-with-handle or double-bottom base. Here's a quick explainer on how to identify a proper flat base.Alphabet is a fairly typical example of a flat base. The stock broke out of a double-bottom base with a 753.58 entry in late July. Shares peaked at 813.88 on Aug. 11, then began consolidating in a sideways. Shares never fell more than 4% from the high, finding support last week just above the 50-day moving average, closing Friday at 797.97. The flat base entry point is 813.98.Alphabet shares rose early but closed down 0.3% at 795.39 on the stock market today.Fundamentals: Q2 adjusted earnings rose 20% vs. a year earlier, picking up from 14% in Q1. Total revenue growth has trended higher, with Q2's 21% increase the best in two years. Core revenue, which excludes traffic acquisition costs -- what it pays partner websites to carry ads -- climbed 22%.RELATED:Google Rebounds With Big Q2 EPS, Revenue BeatNvidia makes chips for gaming, autonomous driving and artificial intelligence.The stock had a long run up before peaking at 63.50. Shares moved sideways, finding support at the 50-day line on Sept. 12 as rebounded last week. At five weeks, Nvidia now has a flat-base pattern with an 63.60 buy point. Nvidia closed Friday at 62.86.Nvidia rose 1.3% to 63.67 after climbing as high as 65.26. The stock closed just above the pivot point, but volume ended about average. It's a tough time to be making any new buys, in any caseFundamentals: Earnings skyrocketed 700% in the latest quarter. Sales rose 24%, the fifth straight quarter of accelerating growth.RELATED: IBD 50: 4 Top Stocks Rebounding Off Key Support LinesNvidia Unveils Artificial-Intelligence Tech For Baidu Self-Driving CarsTexas Instruments is a chipmaker serving industries such as mobile devices and the automotive industry.TI peaked at 72.58 on Aug. 26, gapping higher a day after reporting strong quarter results. After moving tightly for several weeks, shares fell below their 50-day line on Sept. 9. Shares rose 4% last week, regaining that key support level and closing at 69.36. The buy point is 72.68.Texas Instruments stock rose 0.3% to 69.54.Fundamentals: Q2 earnings rose 17%, the third straight quarter of faster growth. Sales rose 1%, the first increase in five quarters.RELATED:Big Cap 20: Tight Action On A Stock Chart Is A Bullish SignAmong Tech Stocks, Chips Still In Driver's Seat; Can It Continue?Tesla Autopilot Update: Which Suppliers Should Be On Your Radar?Equifax provides information and risk services to consumers and businesses, offering reports, risk scores and analytics.Equifax had a big run from early February to late July. Shares peaked at 136.97 on July 26. Shares have moved sideways since then. It's been finding support near the 50-day line for the past month, though it closed at 132.21 on Friday, just below that support level. The stock has a buy point at 137.07.Equifax reversed to trade down 0.5% at 131.55.An extra note of caution. Equifax is in a fourth-stage base. Late-stage bases are more likely to fail.Fundamentals: Q2 earnings rose 24%, the best quarterly gain in three years. Sales climbed 20%, the most in several years. It was the second straight quarter of accelerating growth on the top and bottom line.RELATED:The New America: This Top-Rated Data Analytics Firm Is Seeing Exploding Growth

Germany's Bosch supplies radar sensors for Tesla's (TSLA) Model S and presumably will benefit from Tesla's new radar-focused Autopilot feature, but other suppliers conceivable also could benefit.Texas Instruments (TXN), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and Delphi (DLPH), along with Bosch, are among "key players" in automotive radar technology, research firm Stratistics MRC identified in a July report. The report identified Freescale Semiconductor as a key player, but NXP has completed its $11.8 billion acquisition of Freescale.Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) is among the few companies identified as a Tesla supplier, providing some of the technology used in Tesla's self-driving car efforts.IBD'S TAKE: Fast growth, and solid prospects, for its automotive chip business is a major catalyst driving shares of Nvidia, which ranks No. 8 in the latest IBD 50 list of stocks that have performed the best over the past 52-weeks, with an emphasis on the most recent six months.In a blog post Sunday, Tesla said that within a few weeks it will roll out software upgrade Version 8 to its Autopilot feature that will rely more on radar signals rather than cameras. Tesla CEO said this change "very likely" would have prevented a Model S crash in May that killed a driver who was using Autopilot. Authorities are investigating.Currently, the Autopilot system relies more cameras, but Tesla has used radar in the system since October 2014. In its blog post Sunday, Tesla said that "after careful consideration, we now believe it (radar) can be used as a primary control sensor ... ." The company announced other improvements to Autopilot, and Tesla stock was up 2% to 198.30 in the stock market today.Spokespersons for Texas Instruments and Tesla didn't immediately respond to a request for comment. An NXP spokesperson declined to comment. The company is active in the radar/ADAS (advanced driver assistant systems) field.Alphabet (GOOGL) and Apple (AAPL) are among the many companies driving to compete in the fast-emerging self-driving car field.NXP stock and Texas Instruments stock were both up 1.9%, while Delphi stock was up 1.5%. Nvidia rose 2.1%.RELATED:Mobileye Stock Falls; Tesla Shifts To RadarNvidia, NXP Semi, Hawaiian, Boeing Top Tuesday Investing Action PlanApple's Mythical Car Stalls, Stripped For Parts

First, no funds are dumping shares, which would create wild, red streaks on an IBD multicolor chart (down days and weeks are painted in red). Second, it often points to a supportive general market. Intel (INTC) is supplying communications chips for the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 7, a teardown of one handset by research firm Chipworks revealed Friday."The Intel and Apple iPhone 7 rumors have been circulating around for a while," Chipworks said in a blog post. "However today seeing is believing and we have indeed found an entire Intel mobile cellular platform inside the iPhone 7. Intel supplied not just one, but two RF (radio-frequency) transceivers, the baseband modem, and the (RF) power management IC (integrated circuit)."Intel is taking some business that would have gone to Qualcomm (QCOM), analysts say.Intel stock jumped to a more than 15-year high on Friday after the company raised its third-quarter sales guidance. Intel is scheduled to report Q3 earnings on Oct. 18.Intel shares rose 3% to 37.67 on the stock market today. Shortly after the opening bell, Intel stock reached as high as 38.05, its best reading since January 2001.IBD'S TAKE: Intel has an IBD Composite Rating of 88, meaning it has outperformed 88% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. Intel ranks No. 9 out of 38 stocks in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group. To see which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.The Chipworks teardown of the iPhone 7 handset also showed that Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) had replaced Murata in the diversity receive RF modules.Plus, Chipworks confirmed that Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) is making the Apple-designed A10 processor in the iPhone 7.Other chip suppliers in the iPhone 7 include Broadcom (AVGO), Cirrus Logic (CRUS), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Qorvo (QRVO) and Texas Instruments (TXN), Chipworks said.A teardown of an iPhone 7 Plus by iFixit found a Qualcomm chips, confirming the dual-sourcing rumor. Qualcomm provided the iPhone 7 Plus modem, transceivers and power management IC, iFixit said in a blog post.RELATED:Broadcom, Cirrus Logic Get Lift From iPhone 7 PreordersApple News Positive For Broadcom, Negative For Qualcomm

Apple (AAPL) iPhone 6 and 6 Pluses are dying of "Touch Disease," an ailment resulting from the phones' thin frame -- also known as the 2015 "Bendgate" scandal -- rendering two touch chips unusable, according to repair expert iFixit.Touch Disease first manifests as a flickering gray banner across the top of the screen. Later, it causes glitches in a phone's touch function, and eventually, the phone stops responding to touch. That's a big deal when unlocking the screen requires touch.Repair shops see hundreds of Touch Disease-afflicted iPhones a month, says iFixit. Apple Geniuses -- support staff at the Genius desks at Apple stores -- reportedly acknowledge the problem but can't perform the hardware fix, according to complaints on Apple's forum.The problem seems to be structural. In 2015, Apple strengthened weak points in the iPhone 6 frame to resolve Bendgate -- the phones' penchant for molding to a user's backside while in his or her pocket.Still, the iPhone 6 is highly bendable. Through regular use, the solder beneath two touch chips tends to crack, says iFixit. When those chips lose contact with the logic board, touch functionality goes out the window.Flexing the phone allows the chips to regain contact, but it's a temporary fix. Apple will replace the iPhone 6 while still in warranty, but outside that can only recommend buying a new phone at full price or a third-party repair, iFixit says.Apple didn't immediately return a request for comment.IFixit identifies the touch chips as U2402 Meson and Cumulus U2401, but doesn't note the suppliers. In an earlier teardown, Broadcom (AVGO) and Texas Instruments (TXN) were seen to supply a touch controller and a touch transmitter, respectively.Apple closed down 0.75% to 108.03 in the stock market today, but is forming a handle in a 4-month consolidation. Broadcom lost 1.15% to 175.30, a day after hitting a record high. Texas Instruments dipped 0.1% to 69.90.IBD'S TAKE: Apple has been rallying since hitting a two-year low in May. The iPhone maker is a long way from its all-time highs and the company is set to report its third straight quarter of falling earnings and revenue, but shares are near a buy point. For more details on Apple and other stocks to watch, check out Thursday's Investing Action Plan.RELATED:Apple's Smartphone Profit Share Slipping Vs. SamsungApple Stock Gets Price Target Hike On Improved iPhone 7 OutlookApple Pressuring iPhone Component Suppliers For Price Cuts.

Apple (AAPL) iPhone 6S demand improved in July, but a shift to the lower-end iPhone SE could pressure Apple's component suppliers such as Cirrus Logic (CRUS), Qorvo (QRVO) and Synaptics (SYNA), Pacific Crest analysts said Friday.Meanwhile, Analog Devices (ADI), Broadcom (AVGO) and InvenSense (INVN) will withstand a looming 15%-20% cut on iPhone 7 component orders, but not because of any changes in Apple trends.In July, carriers had six days of iPhone 6S inventory on hand, dropping from a year-high of nine days in April, the investment bank said in a research note. Meanwhile, iPhone SE demand normalized, rising from north of one day in May and June to six days in July.Pacific Crest targets six to 10 days of on-hand inventory for carriers. Inventory rocketed early in the year, as Apple experienced its first dip in iPhone sales."Carrier store inventory declined month over month to the low end of our target," Pacific Crest analysts wrote in a research report. "We view this as encouraging ahead of the iPhone 7 launch in September."But that launch, expected next month, comes with a muted forecast. Pacific Crest sees component orders declining 15%-20% for the iPhone 7 vs. its predecessor iPhone 6S in 2015.Many chipmakers, including Apple suppliers Analog Devices, InvenSense, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Texas Instruments (TXN), during their most recent earnings calls, predicted slower year-over-year demand for their consumer/mobile units."We're not expecting ... any outlandish unit growth in the mobile market," Cirrus Logic CEO Jason Rhode said on the company's fiscal Q1 earnings conference call on July 27. "We've got something of a content story this year."IBD'S TAKE: Broadcom ranks No. 1 in IBD's 41-company Electronic-Semiconductor Fabless industry group. The group has climbed to No. 10 out of 197 groups tracked, up from No. 65 only 13 weeks ago. Get IBD's Stock Checkup to examine individual chipmakers.Pacific Crest maintained sector weight ratings on Cirrus Logic, Qorvo, Skyworks Solutions and Synaptics. The likely transition to digital headsets is already baked into Cirrus Logic stock, and the more conservative iPhone 7 cycle will offset content gains for Qorvo, analysts wrote.Synaptics, on the other hand, is poised for share loss at Apple, Pacific Crest predicted. Synaptics supplies a touch-chip for Apple iPhones, but that could be at risk as Apple reportedly makes the move to OLED (organic light-emitting diode) screens in 2017.OLED technology allow for thinner and more flexible screens, but they are also double the cost of LCD (liquid crystal diode) screens, which Apple uses now. The switch will likely add $30 to $35 to the total bill of materials for the iPhone 8, analysts say."We believe there could be risk that Apple looks to squeeze its other component suppliers on price in order to recoup the incremental BOM associated with the OLED display," the Pacific Crest analysts wrote.In the meantime, Apple suppliers such as Analog Devices, Broadcom and InvenSense stand to outperform, Pacific Crest said. It has overweight ratings on all three stocks.Broadcom is positioned to benefit from the carrier aggregation trend as more infrastructure is built to support 4G and LTE, says Pacific Crest. Analog Devices recently announced its $14.8 billion plan to acquire Linear Technology (LLTC), a move that cuts its Apple exposure. InvenSense is gaining on augmented reality trends such as with the mobile game "Pokemon Go," they said.On the stock market today, Analog Devices rose 0.4% and Synaptics 0.2%. Shares of Cirrus Logic fell 0.2% while Broadcom climbed 0.6% and Skyworks 0.7%. InvenSense stock was down 1.6%, and Qorvo stock was weaker by 0.55%.RELATED:Broadcom Likely Gained 20% Apple iPhone 7 Content Despite 'Muted' RampApple's Smartphone Profit Share Slipping Vs. SamsungBendgate Repeated? Apple iPhone 6 Suffers 'Touch Disease,' Says iFixitAnalog Devices Tops Q3 On iPhone Ramp, But Consumer Sales Dive

Tesla Motors (TSLA) partner Nvidia (NVDA) is making a grab for NXP Semiconductors' (NXPI) piece of the autonomous-driving market, Needham analyst Rajvindra Gill said Wednesday after Nvidia unveiled the guts of its self-driving engine.On Monday, Nvidia revealed its Parker mobile processor, which the company said is 50%-100% more powerful than other mobile processors. Two Parker chips and two Pascal graphics processing units (GPUs) run the Drive PX 2 system for self-driving.Nvidia beat NXP to the market with its Drive PX 2 platform launch in January. But NXP has the largest share of any single player on the market, at 14.2%, according to market research firm Strategy Analytics, Gill wrote in a research report Wednesday.Infineon, Renesas (potentially attempting to acquire automotive-chip firm Intersil (ISIL)), STMicroelectronics (STM), Texas Instruments (TXN), Robert Bosch, ON Semiconductor (ON), Micron Technology (MU) and Toshiba each have 10% or less of the market, he said.The remaining 39% of the $27.4 billion global advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) market is made up of players with less than 1%. That's likely where Nvidia lands. But Nvidia won't stay there for long, Gill predicts."Capitalizing on the trend toward connective self-driving cars, Nvidia is well positioned to gain not only market share, but also increase its (average sales prices) as autonomous applications should command a higher premium than infotainment computing," he wrote.IBD'S TAKE: Mobileye, too, is shoring up its autonomous-driving offerings by partnering with Delphi, the company said Tuesday. The duo plans to release a Level 4/5 automated driving system to integrate into vehicles in 2019.Parker chips are scalable and can be used to host infotainment, digital instrument clusters and ADAS platforms. Drive PX 2 synthesizes information from sensors, vehicle-to-vehicle information, high-definition mapping and algorithmic processing.Together, that's enough for Level 5 automation, which can run a vehicle without any human intervention. The market is largely focused on Level 2 and 3 automation, which can handle adaptive cruise control and parking assistance, among other functions.But tech giants like Apple (AAPL) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google have big dreams for full automation. During the recent Intel (INTC) Developer Forum in San Francisco, the No. 1 chipmaker delved deeper into its partnership with BMW (BMWYY) and Mobileye (MBLY) for autonomous driving.In early afternoon trading on the stock market today, Nvidia stock was down a fraction, above 62.50, but its shares have soared more than 75% the past three months, and it's an IBD 50 stock.

But rivals have also been revving up. On Monday, Mobileye announced it is teaming up with Delphi Automotive (DLPH) to develop a…

Texas Instruments (TXN) outplayed Apple (AAPL) iPhone weakness on strong automotive growth in Q2, prodding its shares to a 16-year high early Tuesday. But analysts were leery about Q3, even with the iPhone 7 expected to be released Sept. 16.Analog chip sales rose 9% sequentially, but they declined 0.2% vs. last year's Q2, Credit Suisse analyst John Pitzer noted in a research report. But without Apple, he said, analog sales would have grown 4% on a year-over-year basis.Still, "Texas Instruments should be viewed as a positive barometer for the industry... emblematic of the early stages of an upturn despite continued investor concerns related to the macro," Pitzer wrote.Texas Instruments stock rocketed 7.85% to 71.42 on the stock market today. Early gains to 72.58 touched a 16-year high achieved in July 2000.IBD'S TAKE: Texas Instruments shares are about 17% extended from a 60.09 entry point touched June 28 out of a flat base. Investors are typically advised to take profits at 20%. Broadcom stock is about 2% from a 166 entry point. Cirrus Logic stock is about 8% extended from a 38.24 buy point.For Q2, Texas Instruments reported $3.27 billion in sales and 76 cents earnings per share, up 1% and 17%, respectively, vs. the year-earlier quarter. Both metrics topped the consensus of 33 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $3.2 billion and 72 cents.Embedded processing sales grew 9% vs. last year and 4% sequentially. The automotive end-market was strongest in Q2, led by infotainment. Personal electronics grew sequentially but declined year over year, led by a dip in mobile phones.Pacific Crest analyst Michael McConnell expects personal electronics to topple again in Q3, even as Apple's iPhone 7 ramps.For Q3, Texas Instruments guided to $3.34 billion to $3.62 billion in sales and 81-91 cents EPS, up 1% and 13%, respectively, vs. the year-earlier period. On the low end, the guidance topped analysts' views for $3.34 billion and 81 cents, McConnell noted in a report.McConnell rates Texas Instruments stock at sector weight. Pitzer boosted his price target on Texas Instruments stock to 77 from 65, but kept his neutral rating.

Analog Devices' (ADI) $14.8 billion acquisition of longtime rival Linear Technology (LLTC) will cut its Apple (AAPL) exposure to 5%, Morgan Stanley analyst Craig Hettenbach said Wednesday.The deal also could spur more consolidation in the semiconductor industry, says Credit Suisse analyst John Pitzer. Last year, chip sector M&A hit a fever pitch as deals topped $100 billion, including Intel's $16.7 billion Altera buy and Broadcom's $37 billion merger with Avago Technologies."With structurally slowing supply, rising barriers to entry, consolidation and a mix shift in end demand away from consumer, we continue to see scarcity value in semiconductor IP and assets and except M&A to continue to be a prevalent theme," Pitzer wrote in a research report.Hettenbach places Analog Devices among the company of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Broadcom (AVGO) and Microchip Technology (MCHP) as "playing acquirers who can deliver above average (earnings per share) due to synergies."But unlike most recent chip M&A, Analog Devices' move to acquire Linear is largely a technology play, he says.Analog Devices leads the data converter market with 40%-50% share, double that of closest rival Texas Instruments (TXN), though that company will remain much larger than the combined Analog Devices-Linear.Linear, meanwhile, is No. 3 in power management chips."One of the long-standing knocks on Analog Devices was its lack of power management presence, the fastest-growing segment within analog," Hettenbach wrote in a report. "But the Linear deal would clearly change this."IBD'S TAKE: Analog Devices stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 60, meaning it performs in the top half of stocks in terms of key metrics. But it trails Linear stock, which has a CR of 79. Texas Instruments stock, though, leads the group with a CR of 96.Together, Analog Devices and Linear are expected to bring in $5 billion in annual sales, nearly 11% of the total $45.7 billion analog-chip market, Stifel Nicolaus analyst Tore Svanberg wrote in a report. The companies see $150 million in cost savings from their merger.Hettenbach expects those savings to yield $4.45 EPS ex items in 2018. Rosenblatt analyst Kinngai Chan sees $5 EPS ex items by the end of 2020.The acquisition cuts Analog Devices' Apple exposure by a third, Oppenheimer analyst Rick Schafer wrote in a report. Schafer downgraded Analog Devices in December on its growing exposure to "the inherent volatility" associated with Apple.The Linear deal trims Analog Devices' consumer segment to 12% of sales, Schafer says.Non-consumer end markets industrial, automotive and communications have been key to Analog Devices' economic recovery over the past five years, Stifel Nicolaus' Svanberg said.After the acquisition closes, expected in mid-2017, those segments will comprise 82% of total sales, Credit Suisse's Pitzer said.Morgan Stanley's Hettenbach upgraded Analog Devices stock to overweight and boosted his price target to 78 from 56.Svanberg rates Analog Devices stock a buy, and he upped his price target to 78 from 68. Oppenheimer's Schafer has an outperform rating and 80 price target on Analog Devices stock.At the close on the stock market today, Analog Devices shares ended the day up 0.7% to close at 63.33.

Cree soared nearly 11% after reporting that it would streamline to focus on its light-emitting diode (LED) markets, and sell its Wolfspeed radio frequency and power chip business to Germany's Infineon Technologies for $850 million. The company…

Gilead Sciences (GILD), Walt Disney (DIS) and Yahoo (YHOO) were downgraded Tuesday, while rebounding Sprint (S) won an upgrade.Needham downgraded biotech Gilead Sciences to hold from buy. Gilead on Monday reported Q2 earnings that beat estimates, but it also lowered its full-year revenue guidance.Shares sank 8.5% to close at 81.05, gapping below their 50-day average.FBR Capital downgraded media and entertainment conglomerates Walt Disney (DIS) and Time Warner (TWX) to market perform from buy, ahead of their earnings.Time Warner is due to report earnings on Aug. 3, with Disney slated for fiscal Q3 results on Aug. 9.Disney shares dipped 0.7%, and Time Warner lost 0.3%.Morgan Stanley downgraded Yahoo to equal-weight from buy and set a price target of 42 as other analysts reiterated buy ratings. Having sold its core internet business to Verizon Communications (VZ), Yahoo now plans to monetize its stakes in Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group (BABA) and Yahoo Japan.Yahoo rose 1.2% after slipping 2.7% Monday.Pacific Crest Securities upgraded Sprint to sector-weight from sell. "It appears that lower promotion activity during the next few months ahead of the (Apple (AAPL)) iPhone cycle may provide some breathing room for Sprint," said analyst Michael Bowen in a report.RBC Capital and Cowen & Co. both raised their price targets on Sprint, which climbed 5.9% to 6.25 Tuesday after jumping 28% Monday.In other analyst moves, Piper Jaffray initiated Adobe Systems (ADBE) with an overweight rating, while Stifel downgraded a slew of restaurant stocks, including Texas Roadhouse (TXRH), Dave & Busters Entertainment (PLAY), Darden Restaurants (DRI), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), and Panera Bread (PNRA). Bank of America upgraded Texas Instruments (TXN) to buy from neutral.

Stocks rose modestly in early trading Tuesday, as techs led.The Dow industrials rose 0.1% while the  S&P 500 climbed 0.2% and the Nasdaq composite added 0.4%.The Federal Open Market Committee launches its two-day meeting in Washington D.C., which wraps up with a policy announcement scheduled for 2 p.m. Wednesday.Home prices rose at a slightly slower pace in May, sending S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Index up 5.2% vs. April's 5.4% increase. Analysts had projected an acceleration to 5.6%.At 10 a.m., June new-home sales figures are expected from the Commerce Department, while the Conference Board plans to release its July Consumer Confidence Index.Caterpillar (CAT), McDonald's (MCD) and Verizon (VZ) were among the big names to report results early Tuesday. Apple (AAPL), Panera Bread (PNRA) and U.S. Steel (X) are a few names due to report in a busy after-hours session.McDonald's dropped 3% at the open after its second-quarter earnings bested analyst estimates, but revenue just missed and same-store-sales were far short of consensus views. McDonald's is in the 12th week of a cup base -- which eventually could lead to a breakout of the stock -- started after shares notched a record high in May.Texas Instruments (TXN) bolted 7% after a strong second-quarter beat.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose 4% at the open.  The casino owner reported its first year-over-year revenue gain for Sands China in two years, buoying speculation that the Chinese gambling hub of Macau may be showing signs of revival and overshadowing otherwise weak second-quarter results.Israel-based Mobileye (MBLY) opened down 10% and is currently off 8.5%. The maker of camera-based autopilot technologies for cars rose briefly in premarket trading after reporting strong second-quarter results. But Mobileye Chief Technology Officer Amnon Shashua said during the company's quarterly conference call with analysts that Mobileye's relationship with Tesla Motors (TSLA) would not go further than the EyeQ3 processor currently used in Tesla models. Mobileye ended Monday's session more than 100% above a February low, as it climbs the right side of a deep 11-month correction.Tesla shares fell about 1%.Cabinet and plumbing products maker Masco (MAS) climbed 4% after a second-quarter report in which earnings beat expectations, and revenue met views. Management inched up Masco's dividend, and said "the fundamental demand drivers of our end markets remain robust." Masco is now extended from a 33.02 purchase point.Aerospace leaders United Technologies (UTX) climbed 2% and B/E Aerospace (BEAV) was up 7% after solid Q2 reports.Oil futures slipped 1%, sending West Texas Intermediate below $44 a barrel. Gold inched up above $1,321 an ounce. The dollar lost ground, and the 10-year Treasury yield slipped 2 basis points to 1.56%.Overseas, China's markets saw gains, while in Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped 1.4% as the yen rose sharply ahead of the Bank of Japan's two-day meeting set for Thursday and Friday.Europe's major markets were higher in afternoon trade.

SoftBank's (SFTBY) announcement late Sunday of its $32 billion deal to acquire Apple (AAPL) iPhone component supplier ARM Holdings (ARMH) could stoke further M&A activity, with top-five chipmakers -- Intel (INTC), Texas Instruments (TXN), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Broadcom (AVGO) -- cited as potential acquirers.Any company with a $10 billion to $15 billion market capitalization is on the table, says S&P Global Market Intelligence analyst Angelo Zino. Companies valued around $5 billion are in the "sweet spot." Recent rumors have targeted Xilinx (XLNX), which is valued above $12 billion.Marvell Technology (MRVL), Cavium (CAVM), Cypress Semiconductor (CY), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Integrated Device Technology (IDTI) also fit the bill for possible acquisitions, Zino told IBD.Of IBD's 41-company Electronic Semiconductor-Fabless industry group, five names top $15 billion in market valuation: Qualcomm, Broadcom, ARM, Nvidia (NVDA) and NXP.At the close on the stock market today, ARM stock catapulted 40.6% to 66.17 and at an all-time high. That helped pull the IBD Electronic Semiconductor-Fabless industry group up 2%, hitting a 13-month high. Meanwhile, Apple gained 1.1% to 99.88. Qualcomm, which reports earnings later this week, also added 1.1%, and ended the day at 55.35. Broadcom advanced 0.7% to 162.33. Intel, which has struggled to enter the low-power microprocessor market dominated by ARM, ticked down 2 cents to 35.05.IBD'S TAKE: The Electronic Semiconductor-Fabless industry ranks No. 24 out of 197 groups tracked and includes leaders like Nvidia, the group's No. 1-ranked Monolithic Power Systems, Silicon Motion Technology, Broadcom and MaxLinear. All five have Composite Ratings of 99, meaning they perform in the top 1% of all stocks in key metrics such as earnings and sales growth."Intel and Qualcomm are sitting on a hoard of cash, and both have concerns with regards to growth," Zino said. "Broadcom, formerly Avago, has done a phenomenal job with acquisitions over the last three years. They're at a point now where they're looking to increase their war chest over the next 12 to 18 months."Canaccord analyst Matt Ramsay puts Silicon Laboratories (SLAB), Cavium and GoPro (GPRO) supplier Ambarella (AMBA) on his potential takeover list, but says he doesn't see ARM as a target. U.K.-based ARM treats its licensees with a very "vendor neutral approach" and wasn't bandied on the typical rumor mill."After last night's news, I wouldn't put anything (in M&A) past anybody," Ramsay told IBD. "I don't think anything is off the table. Bigger companies buying differentiated tech is not off the table."What's newer is companies doing more financial-engineering-type mergers, where it's a merger of equals to protect earnings growth and cash flow growth."But 2016 M&A won't resemble the frenzy of 2015 chip-sector deals, when the value of M&As rocketed above $115 billion. In 2015, companies were buying innovation. Such was the case when Intel spent $16.7 billion to acquire field-programmable gate array (FPGA) maker Altera. This year, companies will be buying earnings leverage."The semiconductor space has seen a dramatic slowdown in growth, and there's going to be a move by larger players to generate growth and earnings leverage via acquisitions," Ramsay said. "You've got fairly healthy balance sheets across the sector here, and because of that, you're going to see more M&A."Zino added: "But in terms of dollar amount, you're not going to see what you saw in 2015 again."Smartphone growth slowed to 10% in 2015 from 29% in 2014, Zino said. That's tugged at the bottom line for Apple iPhone suppliers like Qualcomm and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), which analysts expect to report a respective fifth and sixth quarter of decline later this week.This year, Zino expects smartphones to decelerate to 5%-6% growth. Canaccord's Ramsay is less bullish -- he views flat growth for 2016. For 2017, though, Apple's iPhone 8 "super cycle" could lend itself to 5% growth, Ramsay told IBD. And niche sectors like video, gaming and automotive will continue to growth.On the latter point, the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas in January used to be all about smartphones, but automotive and self-driving efforts by Apple, Alphabet (GOOGL) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) have pressed chipmakers into a new role, Ramsay says, noting, "Now, there's a car in every booth."

Silicon Valley's namesake raw material faces a promising new rival: gallium nitride (GaN). Some say the newcomer is poised to swarm the $30 billion semiconductor power supply market. It's a market that involves "anything that plugs into a wall" ranging from Apple (AAPL) iPhone chargers to Tesla Motors' (TSLA) luxury electric cars. Chips using layers of GaN have the potential to…

Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 7 ramp and "less bad" PC sales will lead to an in-line second quarter for chipmakers, but Brexit-fostered macro worries could play out in October-quarter earnings, Credit Suisse and MKM analysts said Friday.Credit Suisse analyst John Pitzer's top picks include Broadcom (AVGO), Intel (INTC), Analog Devices (ADI), Lam Research (LRCX), Microchip Technology (MCHP) and Mellanox Technologies (MLNX)."Importantly, (the second half of 2016) should be up 2.5% year over year after four quarters of year-over-year declines," Pitzer wrote in a research report. But overall he expects 2016 chip sales will be flat vs. earlier expectations for 3.8% growth.IBD's TAKE: IBD's 33-company Electronics-Semiconductor Equipment industry group is currently No. 48 out of 197 groups tracked, having made big moves over the last eight weeks from No. 169. It's led by ASML in market value, but KLA-Tencor tops the group in terms of Composite Rating. KLA has a CR of 92, meaning it outperforms 92% of all stocks in key metrics.Apple iPhone suppliers -- including Broadcom and Analog Devices -- could benefit from a "lackluster iPhone 7 cycle" still likely to grow 55%-60% from 80 million units shipped in the first half of the year."Overall, handsets (are) better," he wrote. "Slowing Samsung Galaxy S7 and weak high-end China (are) offset by mid- to low-end iPhone 7 builds."More PC-oriented Intel and Microchip could benefit from marginal improvements in shipments, Pitzer wrote. During Q2, units declined 4.5% vs. last year, but topped the four-quarter average of a 12% decline. Still, expectations for PC builds to fall 8% this year would be conservative.Industrial trends improved modestly over the last 90 days, but appear seasonally weaker in the second half of 2016 -- likely impacting Lam. Lam, which is trying to acquire KLA-Tencor (KLAC), competes against ASML (ASML) and Applied Materials (AMAT) in the chip gear-making sector.Mellanox, on the other hand, could benefit in the second-half on infrastructure improvements by Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT). Mellanox's products are used to connect servers, provide storage and tie hyper-converged infrastructure -- a necessity for major cloud operations.The real risk is in Q3, when the effect of the U.K.'s decision to exit the European Union are likely to play out, Pitzer says. Global stock markets toppled on the Brexit vote and Q3 expectations that are already above seasonal quarter-over-quarter growth leave plenty of room for disappointment.MKM analyst Ian Ing sees the Brexit effect slugging Xilinx (XLNX), Texas Instruments (TXN), Intersil (ISIL), ON  Semiconductor (ON) and Analog Devices -- which have high distribution-channel sales "which are a proxy for European and industrial market exposure."Xilinx and Texas Instruments derive about 60% of their sales through the channel, according to U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filings. Intersil, ON and Analog Devices take in more than half of their revenue from distribution."Industrial markets which are served by distributors are expected to have seasonally weaker second half of demand compounded by perceived Brexit risk and uncertainty," Ing wrote in a report. "Q3 and Q4 are expected to be down seasonally and likely further exacerbated by customers' Brexit uncertainties."The most obvious effect is in currency adjustments. Following the vote, the British pound fell 9.3% vs. the U.S. dollar to its lowest point in decades. The euro fell 1.6%.
